steps.title: ”OMW” can mean “On My Way.”
steps.content: ”OMW” can mean “On My Way.” The most common phrase that “OMW” stands for is “on my way.” People often use “OMW” to quickly convey that they’re headed to a specific location. [1] X Research source ”OMW” is used so often as an abbreviation for “On My Way!” that Apple has even programmed its devices to autocorrect “OMW” to “On my way!” [2] X Research source

steps.title: "OMW” can mean “Oh My Word.”
steps.content: "OMW” can mean “Oh My Word.” Some people use “OMW” as a shorthand for “oh my word” which makes for a less controversial alternative to “oh my God.” [3] X Research source

steps.title: Text “OMW” to tell someone you’re en route.
steps.content: Text “OMW” to tell someone you’re en route. Sending someone a quick “OMW” is a simple yet helpful way of letting someone know you’re headed towards them. [4] X Research source “In the car. OMW.” “Just showered, OMW now.” “OMW. I should be there around 3.”

steps.title: Use “OMW” to hide that you’re running late.
steps.content: Use “OMW” to hide that you’re running late. 14 minutes away when you should be 4? Use “OMW!” Because “OMW” is vague and doesn’t include an estimated arrival time (or any other info for that matter), it can help cover your tracks when time gets the better of you. [5] X Research source “OMW. But there’s traffic 🙁” “OMW. See you soon! 😄” “Save me a seat, I’m OMW!”

steps.title: Message “OMW” instead of “On My Way!”
steps.content: Message “OMW” instead of “On My Way!” for a more neutral tone. While their meaning is the same, “on my way!” has a very different tone than “OMW.” If you’re going to meet someone in a professional context (or you just don’t want to appear too excited), abbreviating “on my way” and replacing the exclamation point with a period is a safe bet. [6] X Research source To be even more subtle, you can send “omw” in all lowercase. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Type “OMW” as a shorthand when gaming online.
steps.content: Type “OMW” as a shorthand when gaming online. Many believe that “OMW” rose to popularity in the early 2000’s in the chatrooms of online games like Runescape and World of Warcraft. When players wanted to call for backup but needed their hands on the keyboard to defend their characters, sending “OMW” to friends saved them time and points. It could do the same for you! [8] X Research source “OMW to your dungeon now! Hold tight!” “OMW! Can you get him to 50 HP for me?” “OMW how hard is this boss?”

steps.title: Punctuate your surprise with “OMW.”
steps.content: Punctuate your surprise with “OMW.” Since “oh my word” is an alternative for “oh my God,” use “OMW” to convey the same shock you would if you were saying “OMG.” [9] X Research source “OMW you’ll never guess what just happened!” “OMW this rain is crazy!” “OMW I did not expect Tony and Sandra to get engaged this soon!”

steps.title: Use “OMW” to vent your anger.
steps.content: Use “OMW” to vent your anger. When spelled-out words don’t feel like enough, or they feel too frustrating to type, “OMW,” like “OMG,” is an effective way to show someone you’re exasperated over text. [10] X Research source “OMW I’m so sick of these rude customers!” “OMW! Who does that jerk think he is?!” “OMW I can’t even 🤬🙄”

steps.title: Convey excitement with “OMW.”
steps.content: Convey excitement with “OMW.” Just got a promotion? Your favorite restaurant chain opened up a block from your house? An all-caps “OMW” is a perfect exclamation of joy! “OMW! GUESS WHO GOT HER DRIVER’S LICENSE?” “OMW I MADE DEBATE FINALS!” “OMW! THAT’S WONDERFUL! I’M SO HAPPY FOR YOU!”

steps.title: Confirm you received their update.
steps.content: Confirm you received their update. If someone texts you “OMW” to let you know they’re in transit towards you, it’s polite to acknowledge you got their message. “Got it. Thanks!” “Okie dokie. See you soon!” “👍”

steps.title: Get more info if they’re being vague.
steps.content: Get more info if they’re being vague. If you have a hard deadline or time you need to start and someone only texts you “OMW,” it’s completely reasonable to ask where they are or for their estimated arrival time. [11] X Research source “Okay. What’s your ETA?” “How far out are ya? I need ya here ASAP!” “Can you share your location so I know where you’re at?”

steps.title: Pry a little if the text feels standoffish.
steps.content: Pry a little if the text feels standoffish. If someone is known for texting colorfully with lots of words and emojis, but merely sends you an “OMW.” message, check in on them. See if there’s been a relationship rift or if you can help. [12] X Research source “Okay. Everything okay?” “Take your time. Also, I’m here if you need to talk.” “Got it. We’re good, right?”

steps.title: Give context for the game if it’s an online message.
steps.content: Give context for the game if it’s an online message. If someone is using “OMW” during a video game, give them more information about what they might need to enhance their gameplay. [13] X Research source “Okay. It’s a water-type so avoid using fire attacks.” “Get here soon. We need 5 players to advance to the next level.” “Okay. Hide your melee weapons! This arena is weird!”

steps.title: Share their surprise.
steps.content: Share their surprise. Half the fun of a surprise is the person’s reaction. If someone hits you with unexpected news, don’t hide your shock! [14] X Research source “NO WAY!” “SERIOUSLY???? “🤯😯”

steps.title: Listen to their frustrations.
steps.content: Listen to their frustrations. When someone texts “OMW” because they’re angry, the best way to be there for them is to validate their irritations and actively listen to their outrage. They want to be understood and to feel vindicated. [15] X Research source “Ugh! That’s so annoying!” “Seriously? I’m so sorry! I’d be PISSED!” “WTF? How dare they!”

steps.title: Match their excitement.
steps.content: Match their excitement. If the tone of an “OMW” text is positive, share that texter’s glee with them. It’ll likely improve both of your moods. “GAAAAAHHHHHH! THAT’S SO EXCITING!” “OMW RIGHT BACK AT YA! I’M SO PROUD OF YOU!” “WOOHOOOOO! 🎉🎇🎊”

steps.title: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms.
steps.content: Stay on top of new texting slang with these common acronyms. Learn these popular slang terms to stay in the know and keep your texts looking like English instead of gibberish: BSF : “Best sister friend” or “best sibling friend” MMK : “Mmkay” (a combo of “mm” and “okay”) HB : “Heartbroken,” “homeboy,” or “how ‘bout?” DL : “Down low” ABS : “Absolutely” WYLL : “What you look like” or “What do you look like?” HYB : “How you been?” ISTG : “I swear to God”
